text: [Music]
[Applause]
thanks for coming everyone I didn't have
any religious schooling as a kid my
family did not go to church so I'm
always surprised to say that one of my
first my actually my first revelation
happened in a church I was um six or
seven years old I was like in first or
second grade and I had spent the night
at a friend's house house on a Saturday
night and in the morning I went with her
family to church the parents went off to
you know the service and I went off with
my friend to the little Sunday school
and at this Sunday school we were given
these booklets and what the booklets
were were these watercolor these
reproductions of watercolors that were
pictures of wild flowers and butterflies
and clouds and all of the natural
wonders and on the opposite page to
these pictures were little poems lyric
descriptions of the images and i' I knew
I'd loved books by then I'd been a
reader my mother had always read to me
and I had already fostered a a real love
of books but I never uh had encountered
the feeling that I had when I read those
descriptions um I I felt for the first
time I saw the Power of Words I saw that
they could harness a beauty that
absolutely pierced me and I remember it
as a moment of real change in my life it
was it was at that moment that I knew um
I didn't know what it was to be a writer
I didn't have any idea someone like me
could be one but I knew that I was going
to spend my life trying to harness that
I was going to try to with words capture
that kind of of beauty um so yesterday I
was when I realized I was going to tell
you about that first revelation I
thought you know since I don't have any
fancy slides or videos or anything like
others have I just have me um I thought
I was I would bring that book because I
I ended up saving it all these years
sort of by accident um and it was in my
basement somewhere I knew that so I went
downstairs in my basement and you know I
should tell you that my basement if the
if the organizers of this thing were in
my basement they would just have
rescinded the invitation um because it
it really clearly identifies me as not
an extraordinary human being at all in
fact a rather shameful one and maybe
some of you relate I'm hoping some of
you relate and I sort of have an excuse
as to why my basement is so hideous
about a year and a half ago my husband
and I um and and our kids moved and we
moved the last couple years have been
the busiest of our lives and so we got
ourselves in this situation where
suddenly it was like in 3 days we had to
be out of our our house and in this
other house and you know we we had these
we have our kids are six and seven and
so they have all this junk that the kids
accumulate and all these years we'd been
just throwing it in the basement and so
what happened is I had to in like 3 days
box everything up and just move it to
the new house I didn't get to go through
things like a good citizen does and
bring things to Goodwill and the dump
and you know so I found myself um and I
keep saying we moved but actually my
husband who's in the room a very
extraordinary man but um useless at
packing useless at packing it's like the
cats were more assistance in this move
than than he was and so I'm by myself in
the middle of the night in the basement
boxing things up and on top this I have
like 101 degree fever because I've
suddenly become ill and so I had reached
this moment um in the middle of the
night on one of these nights packing
where instead of being reasonable and
writing things like kitchen utensils and
kids toys and stuff on the boxes I had
sort of the inner the inner feeling the
inner me was really coming out and so on
the boxes I would write like useless
crap you're too pathetic to get rid of
and then like i' tape it up
pants you're you're always going to be
too fat to fit into so let it go you
know and Taping that up so this is what
I had to encounter yesterday when I
revisit my basement because of course
we've not unpacked these boxes and you
know I never did find that book I don't
have it up here to to show you but it is
in my basement um and but what I did and
this happens to me all the time really
in my life as is somebody who writes
non-fiction this is the sort of stuff um
I'm constantly having a mind and that is
um you know what does this experience
mean what's the greater meaning and I
thought it was a really uh wonderful
kind of metaphor for what I want to talk
to you about today and that
is our deepest Treasures are buried in
the crappy detrus in our life that um
you know so much of that reach for the
extraordinary is bound up um in the the
self-doubt the self-loathing the the
darkness the difficulty um the things
that we bury and I think that everyone
who came up here and stood before you
today knows that to be true that what we
that what we accomplish is built on what
we failed at what we tried at what we
hope to do better someday um and and
that is too you know the title of my
talk ra radical sincerity we often use
this word radical um I think in a way
that isn't quite really uh what it means
we we think of radical we think of
people who are
outside and extreme and and and and and
agitating in some way or bringing in
outside ideas but really the definition
of the word radical is of the root of
the origin the
fundamental and that's what I'm and sin
and sincere means true and so what I
want to talk about today is this I do
think that the journey to extraordinary
is through the true root finding in
ourselves that voice that we know to be
true that we recognize as the voice that
makes the most sense that sometimes it's
in the form of a calling um like that
calling I think I experienced you know
when I when I got that little booklet
that I can't bring you and sometimes it
comes later in life when you realize
that uh you're on the wrong path or
you're married to the wrong person or um
you know you never thought you wanted to
have kids and and suddenly you realize
that you must and I think that that is
you know such a powerful and fundamental
um ingredient of that reach to
extraordinary and I keep saying reach to
extraordinary because I don't think I
think we're all ordinary in this room
and I think we're all Extraordinary too
and so and the only there's the line
between those things is very thin and
the only difference between how you can
get from this side to that side is is is
that reach is that identification of you
know are you following
that um that qu that that that truth
that's at your that at your core um
I followed that really in my early years
I was a very uh ambitious young woman
who who wanted to be a writer and
thought I could be um even though all
these voices around me said well that's
not reasonable and nobody's going to pay
you for that and all those things I
ignore those voices and I mve forward
but something happened along the way um
to make my journey more difficult um and
that is when I was a senior in college I
was 22 my mother suddenly got sick and
died she was 45 she died seven weeks to
the day after she found out she had
cancer and she was really my only parent
she was my my tap rout in a real way and
when she died I didn't know how I could
live without her I had absolutely no
idea how I could thrive in a world
without my mother and um so I had to
figure that out and I did all kinds of
things I first tried to replace my mom I
tried to sustain uh my family and and
sort of fill that hole um that she left
and then I found out I couldn't do that
that that was impossible and so then I
decided to self-destruct and that in
some ways seemed like um in retrospect I
can see in some ways that was like a way
of of honoring my mother to
say I cannot bear this world without her
and so I won't and so I went I actually
came to Portland I was living in
Minneapolis I uh got involved with drugs
I was promiscuous I did a lot of things
that were really harmful to um to myself
and also uh ran at a crosscurrent to
that to that kind of radical sincerity
that core root within me um and it was
because I love my mother so much but
what's interesting to me is so here I
was trying to destroy myself because I
love my mom so much but what saved me is
how much she loved me because I couldn't
forget that I could not forget in the
midst of of My Darkest Hour how much my
mother loved me she used to with my
brother and sister and I when she was
when we were growing up she used to play
this game that I just did with my own
kids this morning and um she would say
do I love you this much and we'd say no
do I love you this much and we'd say no
this much no on and on and on until she
was reaching as wide as she could reach
and the answer was always no the answer
was always that the amount that she
loved us was not containable it was not
within reach and I'm hoping that that
all of you in this room have been loved
like that because once you are loved
that way I do think it's always with you
and so ultimately what I realized in the
midst of
my most difficult
hour um which was really like a
difficult couple you know two or three
years is that that that love existed in
every cell of me and the greatest honor
to my mother would be to live my life as
if that were true um and because that
was the truest truth I decided to do
that so I had to figure out how to do
that I couldn't I couldn't um I had to
do something
sort of incredible or extraordinary even
though I was not incredible and
extraordinary so I decided to uh hike a
trail that I'd never heard of I was
living in Minnesota at the time I was a
waitress and I was standing in line at
an REI store just outside of Minneapolis
I was buying a shovel there had been a
blizzard and I needed to dig my truck
out and I saw this guide book um that
was on this shelf as I was waiting to to
buy my shovel and I picked it up and it
said that Pacific Crest Trail volume 1
California and I had never heard of this
Trail I read the back of the book I
thought it was interesting for those of
you who don't know what it is it's a
Wilderness it's a national Scenic Trail
that goes from the Mexican border to
just past the Canadian border through
California Oregon and Washington um up
the crest of the the Pacific Crest the
CR Nevada and the Cascade Range and I
put it back on the Shelf but I returned
soon after and bought that book I'd
never gone
backpacking a night in my life but I had
grown up in the wilderness of northern
Minnesota I had known what it was like
um to be among the silent and the wild
things and it was my home it was a place
that gathered me and so it was my turn I
guess having lost my my home it was my
it was my way of seeking that um out so
that I can find my footing again so I
did that and I began my hike it was the
summer of 1995 I was 26 years old I
began my hike in the Mojave desert I
didn't know what the hell I was doing um
I put way too much stuff in my backpack
I thought I thought that's what
Backpackers did you just carried a bunch
of out
there um and I should say sorry you know
for months the organizers of this event
would email me and call me and say do
you have any questions do you have any
questions and I was like no I don't have
any questions yesterday I had a question
it was can I say
they said yes so that was an
approved
um so I'm out there and I'm
carrying all this stuff and I really
literally cannot stand up I'm I'm I'm
hunching in a remotely upright position
and the pack everywhere it makes contact
with my body is is rubbing my skin away
and my feet are blistering and I don't
encounter another human being in the um
the first eight days of my hike I was
out there 94 days um and it became the
norm that I would go days on end without
seeing another person and all of that
was um
incredibly difficult for me and
interesting to me and good for me and it
taught me um I I finished my trip at The
Bridge of the Gods at the at the
Columbia River in Cascade Lex Oregon um
two days before my 27th birthday on
September 15th
1995 and what I learned in that Journey
um and I just want to say first you know
I hiked 1100 miles of the PCT there are
a lot of people who have hiked a lot
longer a lot better they were a lot more
you know incredible in what they did and
also my suffering you know I was 22 and
I lost my mom to cancer and I'm not
alone in that I know that that a lot of
you have suffered and so I don't mean to
say that my suffering was greater nor
that my my uh that out that journey I
was on was any more heroic than anything
any number of people have done and
outdone to be certain but it was the
most um heroic thing I had ever done and
that suffering was the greatest that I
had ever suffered and and so I was out
there really trying to come to grips
with my own life which is the thing you
all have to come to grips with that we
all do it's just being human and I did I
learned how to be resilient I learned
about
um I guess the fact that even though
here I was carrying this weight I
couldn't bear I bore it and even though
I couldn't live in a world without my
mother I was living in one and that's a
powerful powerful radical lesson um
I also learned I redefined strength you
know and that strength was a very humble
thing that it was taking the next step
it was going one more mile it was um
lasting another day um and I and I
learned Simplicity I had remembered that
from back in my youth you know that that
there was power in the simple Act of uh
finding water and making your dinner and
watching the sunset and those things
were res restored me and ways that I
cannot overstate um and they have
informed
me uh they they re they reformed my core
um and they have informed everything
I've done since the greatest things I've
done since mothering you know having my
two children and loving them the way my
mother loved me um marrying my husband
and building a relationship that that
feeds us both and and sustains us both
and sustains our family um and writing
my books um and going on you know those
I've written three books now and in
every book every day every time I write
it's it's so hard and it's just as hard
as it was on the trail you know
strapping on that backpack and walking
another day but um you know through that
the ritual of doing that I learned that
I can you know so what I want to leave
you with
today um I guess through that story of
my journey
is um really the most important thing
here we've been talking all day about
extraordinary but all of these things
that everyone has been talking about
everything that I learned on my journey
it's all stuff that's right it's in in
here it's inside of us and we have that
there in abundance and we have you know
it's not all good that stuff that we
have but it's all in there together and
and and it is what we it's it's it's
what will feed us through our lives and
all the all the journeys um where we
reach for the ability to walk that next
day so I thank you and I hope you keep
walking
[Applause]
